For starters if anyone ever told me I would be writing to get people to watch a middle school romance I would have my doubts .
Before I praise this over the moon I would like to warn you that this can be be pretty boring . It lacks any real substance . A major part of the series is pretty everyday like which is boring and also one of the reasons the show is compelling . The 2 main characters are given everything to work with . The supporting cast don't do much but they have a strong purpose and set up the philosophical aspectsof the show nicely . The animation is pretty nice and the best thing about the show is probably the use of music . Every music used is a good fit for the running scene . The storytelling is so simple and yet so subtle . The quote references are very relatable and answer certain questions for you . The use of psychology was also something to behold .Adolescence was portrayed fairly well as well . The script was quite good and skipped the unnecessary generic lines which worked to sell the characters . However the direction in this series is where it deserves its main praise . Doing everything it can to sell the main characters and their awkward feelings . The supporting characters don't do much . But in reality their script plays a valuable role in telling us how middle schoolers have started to think and how their change in mentality affects one another . Tsuki ga kirei doesn't offer much when it comes to the thrills . Its rather about the artistic way everything was brought up . It can potentially change you as a person due to the subtle philosophical outlook that was presented in the show .\n
Wait wait wait I said it lacks substance . So why is this good ? I believe the message told here is the reality . Life doesn't have the substance we expect it to have . During Adolescence we have this strong desire to grow up fast . Not everything we do makes sense and thats how it is . But our feelings are something we can't change at will . Sometimes our curiosity leads us to experiment with our life and most of the time it hurts . But you do that because you look for something new , something strong enough to change you as a person . The answer to that in the show is 'love' . They use it to showcase the characters and their changes . The show tests the characters with different teenage obstacles and gives us a solution / better picture of a lot of things . The emotional side is strong and does its job although that is debatable . This is no fairy tale . Things are as close as it is in real life . The ending can be interpreted as a moral lesson as well . (no spoilers ) \n
In short the series not only manages to capture the casual audience with a touching story , its philosophical representation and reality based writing is good enough to change your view / have a better concept on certain things . Then again art is so subjective and a writers way of presentation may not impress everyone . But when a show can do all those mentioned above you know it manages to do its job .

Romance stories usually deal with the love between two people. Even when more than two people are involved in love triangles and such, most of the time the story is about which pairing will end up being the pairing. Aside from this kind of love, however, we sometimes lose sight of the other people who love us in life. Family, friends. Of course, when we get into this area, we have crossed genres entirely.
Tsukigakirei is about the love between two people. And in a sense, these two people will be the main focus of the story throughout. However, the usual way this focus is appliedin many romance anime, nowadays, seems to be to focus just on these people who are involved in the actual romance, and maybe one or two support characters who only get to be there because they will have a direct effect on the romance. Any tension or drama that is generated will arise from misunderstandings (which over repeated usage at best make the characters seem a bunch of idiots, and at worst leads the audience to start questioning the skills of the writer), love rivalry, or just poor luck or bad situations.


There is more to our lives than our boy/girlfriends, however. Even as a middle school student, you have a social circle, your own hobbies, ambitions, obligations (and as a side note, activities could fit into several of these categories), and of course, your family, who try to keep your best interests at heart, but that sometimes means they push you into making a particular choice, and sometimes means they will disagree with your (in hindsight, perhaps a bad) decision. Maybe this kind of drama is not as exciting, but in Tsukigakirei, it resonates.


While watching this, I enjoyed watching two people play the game of romance. It is for this purpose that we enjoy romance stories, after all. But equally, I enjoyed watching two people try to get through middle school life, with all its various obligations, at the same time. I will note that I say "people" here, not "characters", because at some point, I became heavily invested in these two, for a variety of reasons, though I believe the largest of which is that I got to see their circle of friends, and their supporting families. These are the people who we also love, though perhaps in a different way, and I could see that they were as important to each other as the people I care about in my own life.


One final thing. Tsukigakirei has, as far as I can recall, no internal monologue. We never know what any of the people are thinking other than what we see displayed on their faces, or what they say out loud. Because complex misunderstandings leading to fights between couples is not what this story is about. And because the writer and the animators are skilled enough that they can show us information about what these people are going through, without having the character explicitly spell it out for us.


The moon is beautiful, isn't it?

I should preface this by saying that Tsuki ga Kirei is far from a perfect anime. While the background art is gorgeous, the characters themselves are often very inconsistently drawn and the background characters are almost always CG'd very badly and distractingly. And while the characters are lovable and relatable, the grunting noises that the main boy Kotarou makes when he's frustrated (in the Japanese dub at least) are really annoying to me. But despite these things and a few other small details, I still consider Tsuki ga Kirei to be a masterpiece in storytelling and likely my personal favorite anime of the 400+ I'veseen.


In its 12 episodes, this show focuses on one main thing: the relationship between protagonists Kotarou Azumi and Akane Mizuno. Any other drama that occurs in the show itself is somehow tangentially related to their relationship, and anything else is left to the cute shorts after the ED. By focusing exclusively on one thing, it gives the relationship the time it needs to flesh out before the viewer. And it definitely takes its time at some parts. Some parts of the show are almost agonizingly awkward with Kotarou and Akane just sitting, unsure of what to do next and not wanting to make a wrong move. But as awkward as these scenes are, I think they very appropriately capture an important part of their relationship, and reflect the two characters' personalities as well.


Other small details in the show like Akane's potato sack that she plays with the ease her anxiety and Kotarou's boxing with his lamp pull-string add depth to the characters and give us a bit of insight into the quirky middle schoolers that they are. And these details are very welcome in a show where a decent amount of the characters' interactions happen over text message (LINE specifically), with no accompanying dialogue. I've heard people complain about the obnoxious LINE product placement, but I think the show is just being realistic. That's what Japanese kids use these days! Their social interactions occur over LINE, and in conversation that talk about it as such.


When the characters are being quiet, though, the backing music is fantastic. It's usually quiet and unassuming, much like the characters themselves, and it perfectly captures the moods in the show. The OP and ED are equally fantastic, with the ED in particular giving me butterflies after every episode because of how cute it sounds after something good happening in the show.


Overall, Tsuki ga Kirei is a beautiful show. The characters feel real and relatable, and they both have lives outside of the relationship, with Kotarou being an aspiring writer and participant in a local festival's parade, and with Akane being a track star. They don't need each other, and if not for them just being put in the same class, they may never have started dating. But the series shows the viewers how they happened to come together and why they're attracted to each other. Watching them grow as a couple and as individuals is a pleasure to watch, and I would recommend it to anyone that likes a good romance show.

Warning possible Spoilers
I may have finally found the gem of the spring 2017 anime's because despite having a very simple story that is all it needed really and it had great characters to back it up.
The story is about Kotarou Azumi an aspiring writer and Akane Mizuno a track team member who end up in the same class, they start out as complete strangers until after a few occurrences where they slowly develop feelings for each other until Azumi ask's one question that would change their lives.
Now what I really like about the story is how simple it is it doesn't use complex story elementsto get to the next point and instead it just use's the characters interactions and the situations they encounter to keep the plot moving and it does this in a really good way, it also does what usually my favourite romances do is have the main characters ending up together before the series has finished so you get to see how Kotarou's and Akane's relationship develops and the development of their relationship is the best thing about the show as it starts out it very little interaction and most of the time they communicate by texting though as time goes by they become more comfortable with each other and start talking more than they do texting, their relationship does go through a few bumps and turns too since there are other people who have affection for these characters, but luckily these situations were handled very well and in a surprisingly mature way in fact this whole show was actually very mature compared to many other anime's that do romance.

What I also liked about this show is that at the end of most episodes there were these short episodes that give you short snippets of the other characters in the show and how their relationships went as the main characters weren't the only ones in a relationship.


There isn't really much to say about the characters other than the main two because the show pretty much focuses on them, but the supporting characters do have their moments.

Kotarou and Akane are the main characters of the anime and they are very similar characters who do different things, their personalities are mostly the same as they both act shy and awkward around people they aren't familiar with, but are much more open once they get to know each other and their friends, they both care about their friends too often helping them out to the best of their abilities and they are also very mature too which was a bit of a surprise as the situations they got caught up in they actually handled them very well.

Nishio Chinatsu and Takumi Hira are the two characters who have crushes on the main characters, Nishio is Akane's best friend and develops a crush on Kotarou as he got on very well with her, she is actually a kind and thoughtful girl as she even supports Akane's relationship even though she has a crush on Kotarou and Takumi is the track team leader who has a crush on Akane, he is a reliable and attentive person who takes good care of his team, both of these characters do accept the fact that Kotarou and Akane are in a relationship the only time they interrupt the relationship is so they can tell the characters how they feel so they can get it off their chest instead of continuing to pursue them which nicely made the love triangles short lived.

Kotarou and Akane both have their group of friends who pretty much act like any normal junior high schooler as they are always a source of comedy for the show and often tease the man characters, but they can be a bit nosy in their business as they find Akane and Kotarou's relationship interesting since all of their relationships are a pain to deal with in some way.

You also have the main characters family to deal with too who are mainly concerned about their education especially Kotarou's family who are much more strict than Akane's, though not a major part of the story until near the end they do show that being a parent isn't an easy job.


Now the artstyle is different compared to other anime's that I've seen and one thing that sticks out is the white shine on the side of people's face's that did seem oddly distracting sometime's luckily I did get used to it, there is also quite an abundance of CGI here especially with people walking in the background which did ruin some of the scenery, however there are scene's like the festival's that Akane and Kotarou went to that looked really amazing.

I thought the soundtrack was pretty good too it really helped out with the sentimental scene's that Akane and Kotarou had which made the scene's have a little more emotional impact.


Now the Romance was very well done as you really see the development between Akane and Kotarou who start out as awkwardly stuttering people to very well communicative and caring couple and seeing their journey was brilliant, they had great chemistry and were friggin adorable especially during the sentimental scene's and when their relationship encountered a problem they dealt with it in a very mature fashion and faced the problem straight away instead of leaving it to make things worse which nicely got rid of some cliche's I have seen in other romance's.

There was also the Love triangle's too which seemed like the only thing appropriate as a situation in this romance, but it was handled properly and the characters who liked the MC's weren't dislikeable either and gave up once they knew the Akane and Kotarou were together well aside from them confessing, but that was more for closure really.


Even though it doesn't say it in the genre tags there is some comedy in this anime mainly from the short episodes at the end which mainly showed the other characters relationship's and they were really funny to see even if it was for only a few seconds and pretty much showed that relationships are never easy.


Overall this was a very good and simple romance that is definitely going to be a memorable one from this year so if you're looking for a sweet and simple romance then this is definitely a good choice.

Tsuki ga Kirei is an anime I watched on a friends recommendation. In my opinion, it is best described as a coming of age story about finding oneself, young love, and the stresses of transitioning from a child to a teen and gaining responsibilities. 
The story focuses around 2 MCs, both in their 3rd year of middle school. The boy is a passionate writer, while the girl an aspiring track athlete. Both characters express desires to improve their craft, but also to be accepted by their peers. When the two children finally become aware of each other is where the story truly begins. They slowlybuild a bond throughout the show, and once they begin dating you learn of all the struggles of maintaining contact, growing together, and dealing with the judgment of those around them. 


In order to stray away from spoilers, I will simply give a rundown of my interpretation of the show:


The shows greatest strength is its characters, each character feels like an actual  middle schooler. they fit real tropes, from social statuses to hobbies, and all have their own unique mannerisms. They have a genuine feel such as "the young awkward phase" or the "submissive child" which allows you to really get engrossed in their lives. Though the show is slow, you feel as though your watching real life events. The kids do what kids do, they hang out, they go to school, its as you'd expect of children their age. 


My largest qualm with the show is the use of CG to reduce time spend designing irrelevant people for the background which at times was stiff or distracting, and the pacing at times was almost too slow, these both are clearly personal dissatisfaction. 


Overall, I feel this show sits at around a 7.8 on my scale, in the good-very good stage. The show may have been slow, but you felt connected. You wanted to see what would happen, and the cast is truly precious, if not memorable. Each character model was  quite nice and The plot (while slow moving) was delivered cleanly, with little to no physical hiccups to the characters or the stories progression. This show was a gentle, sweet experience. 


My recommendation is if you like romance, cute kids, and relatable authentic characters this may be for you. in the end you're left with a nice bittersweet feeling, and thats something I've always felt was a sign of a well made show. 


Thanks for reading, best of luck in your Anime endevors!

The art is... interesting. I'm not exactly a fan of it, but I'll give it a few points for being different, at least. I didn't really notice the sound, which means that it did its job. If I remember the music, it's either because it was outstanding or horrid.
The story is the relationship between a boy and a girl. There's nothing really special about the story, which is to be expected of a slice-of-life-ish middle school romance anime. It takes a long time for the pace to pick up as well. The plot is fairly predictable, but what happens is pretty heartfelt and sweet, soI feel that it was pulled off well. If you're going to go cliche, then do it well at least.


The characters are decent, at best. They have their own quirks, but there weren't really any stand-out personalities. Note to authors: giving each character one or two funny or unique quirks or traits doesn't make them good characters. Like... "Oh, she squeezes her dolly thingy when she's nervous! What a unique character!" Haha. No. Other characters, who seem like they might play a pivotal role in the story, are just inserted to cause a bit of trivial drama and then fade into the background again. If you're expecting some big drama or plot twists or whatever... let's just say that it's as likely to happen as it does in real life (which could be seen as a good thing if you like realism).


Yeah, although the anime is fairly average, I'm a sucker for romance and PogChamp whenever I see something cute or lovey-dovey. That's where my enjoyment scoring of 9 comes in. For every predictable eye-roll moment that happens, there's a sweet romantic eye-roll inducing moment that put a stupid smile on my face. I felt embarrassed for the characters, I felt sad for them, and I felt happy for them. I'm not sure if Tsuki ga Kirei leaves us viewers with a particularly wise message, but I guess it could happen.


A run-of-the-mill romantic anime that caters to my love of adorableness and the raw adolescent "love will find a way" mentality leaves Tsuki ga Kirei with a score of 8.

(Minor Spoilers Ahead)
Tsuki Ga Kirei is a heartwarming tale of how far a pure first love romance can go. Starting it in middle school with protagonists that are so young and pure it’s hard not to smile with childlike glee when you see them do things for the first time. In fact it’s ironic that these 2 middle schoolers manage to do more than an entire decade of To Love Ru has accomplished.
Plot/Character Development 9/10
None, and I mean none of this what was that I can’t hear you nonsense with a confession, no endless circles or beating around the bush, it’s straight and to thepoint and I like that. Nowadays romance animes seem to try and milk as much screentime as possible out of the show, (mainly due to the majority of them being Light Novel adaptations after all), it’s refreshing to see the pace of how this show was planned out. The main events happen early on to kick start the relationship off yet it manages to not feel forced or rushed at all. It actually seems genuinely believable how this relationship started. You see how they start it off as being awkward to each other and nervous to even talk to another since it’s their first time to becoming more and more accustomed to one another as time goes on in a natural progression that you can actually see happening in a real life situation. Sufficient character development is made with the main characters and they even manage to fit side character development in the span of 12 episodes as well. You can see the tension and anxiety they experience from making choices that could potentially be irreversible and destroy friendships with ones they hold dear with.


Music 10/10

Excellent and I mean damn excellent. The Opening and Ending themes deserve standing ovations on their own but the music in between episodes is absolutely outstanding as well. The music picks are absolutely perfect and actually add a layer of depth to the scene being watched unlike many shows nowadays who add music to a scene to fill the awkward silence or to hide the awkwardness of how some of the lines sound.


Animation 7/10

This is where it gets a bit murky, and you can tell they were definitely trying to cut costs with this one. The art on the main characters and side characters themselves are great, the style itself reminds me of a beautiful rendition of a water coloring drawing and is fantastic on the eyes, at least in my opinion. But dear God the usage of CGI was apparent and often, I’d say on the level of Berserk 2016 bad. You’ll notice within the first 2 minutes of watching the show these stick figures walking they attempted to mold into a human being right next to actual animated characters and that contrast completely breaks immersion while watching the show. If the usage wasn’t that often, I wouldn’t have minded or docked off that much but it is painfully apparent the scope of what they were trying to portray would not fit into the budget they wanted and tried to make due with CGI which was a bad decision in my opinion. The background characters made by CGI look like Kokeshi dolls and I’m not pulling your leg. 


Wrap Up

Tsuki Ga Kirei is an excellent short foray into the romance genre that gets where it needs to be in the span of 12 episodes. There are no loose ends, and you feel fulfilled by the end when you’ve finished it (at least I did binging the thing till 6 AM). Character development is done well despite the episode limits you have unlike certain other romance shows *cough cough Nisekoi*. The Music is an award winner in my book and the art can hold it’s own for the most part if you don’t count the awful large usage of CGI. Is it worth a watch? Yes, every minute of your time spent watching this won’t feel wasted and you’ll end coming out of it feeling truly content with everything wrapped up nicely with a bow tie.


Final Score 9/10

This is only my opinion so don't take it as gospel.
I came across this show by accident and i'm so happy that i did. 
This show is an interesting and engaging tale and is rather unique which is always nice to find in the anime industry. 
The story is one of the most enjoyable romance stories i have ever followed. I'm a bit of a sucker for romance but i feel this show is great for those whom haven't watched a great deal of romance anime. The story for me was relatable which brought it closer to home so to say and i feel itwill be for many others.


The art for the show is not the cleanest that I have seen but is still pleasing to watch. The backgrounds are however some of the best i have seen. 


The sound is good in both dub and sub, I watched the show in dub as I find myself reading the subtitles more then watching the show. I did watch one episode in sub and the sound was fine.

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this show and would strongly recommend you watch it.  The ending is one of the best ways i have ever seen an anime end and that alone is a great reason to watch the show.

I believe anime achieves greatness by being true to itself. Tsuki ga Kirei does that with flying colors by taking the School Life Romance genre template and creating a real story out of that. To avoid any major spoilers, I'll compare it to the movie "Get Out" by Jordan Peele. I know what you're thinking: "whoa, that's a horror movie and this is a school life romance. what could they have in common?" I'll tell you. It is characters who are WOKE. Jordan Peele talks a lot in his interviews about how he wanted to make a MC that you could relate to and wouldn'tdo the dumb horror tropes like walking towards dangerous sounds or being a victim. In the same way, the characters of Tsuki ga Kirei are not oblivious. In many lesser anime of the genre, they will build up character development only to negate it all with something stupid and then put you right back at square one. Tsuki ga Kirei doesn't beat around the bush and provides a realistic and meaningful story of to shy kids trying to find their way.

Tsuki ga Kirei emerges as a soft and refreshing return from recent anime’s of its category. Like new camera models incorporating older designs, Tsuki ga Kirei goes back to basics, focusing on the innocent, nostalgic, and far less melodramatic relationships of old that we recall in our own lives. Free of the hum drum of mainstream anime and its recent ubiquity, the story unfolds honestly, consistently, and with light and subtle flourishes. The combination of these features and the absence of ridiculous progressions (or hindering) in the story and characters allows for an experience that is far more satisfying, in-depth, and true to nature thanthe quick hit, quick elation, anime’s of the same genre.


Looking at it from a much more critical perspective of its work, the art and music flow well with the storyline that the anime endeavours to pedal. A softer approach to art and its muted colour palette, produces a visual aspect that is consistent (something lacking to anime as of late) to the story yet pleasing to the viewer. In regards to the soundtrack (which have always been of heavy interest to me), Tsuki ga Kirei plays the melody of the march it weaves particularly well. It does well in matching elations in sound and in story or contributing curiousity, the spirit of youth, and sheer beauty of life in the peals of its piano strikes, its long and short draws of string, its ambient sound, and/or its use of deafening silence (see wind chime tunnel scene, 14m13s, in Episode 8).


Tsuki ga Kirei is a welcome departure from the status quo but at the same time, its stripped-down view of a pure relationship and the simple and even, nostalgic, story and storytelling warrants a warm and hearty: okaerinasai.

"The moon is beautiful, isn't it?"
How do you express your feelings for another in an awkward, secretive middle school situation? What do you do when you are, or the one you love is, being crushed on by someone else? How do you overcome shyness, barriers and confusion to form a definite and unbreakable love? How do you succeed in your passions, while also succeeding in a relationship with your lover?
Tsuki ga Kirei answers it all.
Honestly, this was probably the most beautiful, heartwarming, feels-inducing anime series I've seen so far. I love the two main characters - Akane and Azumi are both so lovable and realistic!Their shyness, introverted natures and preference to chat over LINE rather than face-to-face is so relatable and lifelike. The storyline and how it is portrayed is amazing and gripping, too. I genuinely felt so tense at parts, and so overjoyed at parts, that I actually screamed out loud. There were times when I was literally cheering out loud, encouraging the charcters, shouting "NO!", and squealing in delight. (My mum must think I'm crazy, lol) ^ O ^\n
The art was beautiful; the sakura, the festival lights, even the everyday images of the school was absolutely stunning. I love how the characters look like real people - no huge eyes, overexaggerated faces, crazy hair, unrealistically skinny bodies or sexualised characters. Everyone looked HUMAN, and that makes me so happy!! I'm also suuuuper glad there were no scenes that would be inappropriate for children, except the odd cuss word and one of the animated shorts containing a sexualised image of a woman in a magazine. I feel uncomfortable watching gory or sexual scenes, so I'm glad there was none of that at all! The music made me want to cry at times, and the voice acting was perfect! The intro and outro made me want to sing along with all my heart. And reading the cute line messages was really interesting... they all make sense in the end...\n
Also, the animated shorts at the end of most episodes made me giggle like a  child > o < \n
Overall, I think this is truly a gem of an anime which everyone should watch. I finished it in 3 days, which is a record for me - I COULDN'T STOP WATCHING IT! If you're into slice-of-life, school, romance, or even sports, you will probably enjoy it!\n
^ w ^

Light spoilers below. Studio Feel will make you feel.
Despite that Tsuki ga Kirei originally seemed destined for obscurity, its rating's recent ascension to an 8.3+ speaks volumes about Studio Feel's ability to enthrall viewers in a fairly simple story about young love.  Put simply, Tsuki ga Kirei is one of those hidden gems whose first few episodes belie its true potential and excellence.  I hope you will decide to give it a chance.
Despite its slow start, Tsuki ga Kirei flourishes alongside our two main protagonists, Akane and Koutarou, as they progress through the familiar struggles of junior high school: exams, clubs, friendships, anddifficult new experiences. Although they are not the most expressive pair, we learn about them through their decisions and conversations as they discover each other.  


Due to their distinct hobbies, personalities, and friend groups, both Akane and Koutarou exist beyond their mutual relationship- allowing the audience to grow closer to each individual while simultaneously investing in them as a couple.  The characters, in general, are actually one of the show's strongest points because they are realistic and believable.  The common romance tropes are left behind completely; there are no accidental boob grabs or simple misunderstandings which balloon to nuclear heights. The characters have problems and they talk to one another. This unique aspect propelled this show from good to great in my eyes because it made the drama more than just believable, it made the drama relatable.  We root for the characters because we see ourselves in them and recognize their mistakes and struggles as our own. We empathize with them even as we bang our heads against the wall because we know that it is truly impossible to have your shit together at the age of 15.


Overall, the plot is realistic and developed. To my surprise, I found that little was left unaddressed or wanting by the end. Perhaps my greatest regret is that the show ended so conclusively that hopes for a second season or continuation are inconceivable.  


Art


Although I do not believe that the art was the apex of Tsuki ga Kirei's excellence, I found the character designs to be appealing and distinguishable.  Be warned, there is occasionally some unfortunate use of cgi to accentuate the backgrounds, but what I once considered an annoyance and an eye-sore quickly was overshadowed by crisp, colorful, and beautiful backgrounds and environments.  As the show progressed, my opinion of the art dramatically increased from just okay to often impressive.  


Sound


The soundtrack for this anime was on point. Both the OP and ED matched the tone and theme of the show and encapsulated the intimate feel that the story espouses. The OST was also rather extraordinary and consisted of several songs which accurately conveyed the scene's emotions and impact.


Enjoyment


Out of all this last season's anime, I looked forward to the release of Tsuki ga Kirei more than any other. I highly enjoyed its ability to bring me back to my freshman year of high school and the challenges of puberty and first loves.  I would definitely recommend it.  


As stated before, one of this anime's greatest achievements is that it was able to avoid the downfall of so many other romances- contrived drama.  The characters, even when they are wrong, act realistically.  Their relationships are authentic and have weight.  Mix in some solid artwork, a fantastic ost, and enjoyable characters, and you get Tsuki ga Kirei- a 9/10 anime that is a gift to those who enjoy anime romances. 


I would also HIGHLY recommend sticking around through the entire ED because many episodes include some shorts.  I would gladly watch an entire show of shorts like these. They are 10/10.

Menurut saya, anime ini adalah anime paling realistis dari semua anime yang pernah aku lihat. Setiap menonton selalu membuat ingin masuk ke dalam cerita tersebut sebagai tokoh utama, bahkan sebagai tokoh sampinganpun tidak masalah. Meskipun cerita percintaan mereka hampir tak ada adegan komedi, tetap membuat ingin tersenyum sendiri. Ditambah lagi lagu pengiring yang digunakan sangat bagus. Episode terakhir banyak adegan yang tak disangka namun tetap realistis. Terlebih lagi bagian terakhir yang luar biasa dengan menampilkan pesan chat LINE  dan gambaran kehidupan masing-masing sampai akhirnya menikah membuat saya terdiam sampai akhir. Hal tersebutlah yang membuat saya memberi apresiasi tinggi dan membuat review pertama sama diMyAnimeList. Terima Kasih.,

I will make this simple.  If you enjoy emotional anime then watch this.  If you've already watched it, watch it again.  This anime is amazing in every way.  
Story:
It's a simple premise.  Middle school students go about their normal everyday life.  Two relatively shy students start dating and we follow their story.  The simplicity is what makes it amazing.  I honestly still don't know why I love this .anime so much but I do and I want to share it with as many people as I can.
Art:
Smooth water colour palate draws more attention to the story andcharacters which are the true star of this.  The ONLY thing that bugged me was the sort of janky 3D models of background characters.  Sadly I am a bit hypervigilant and stuff like this doesn't get passed me.  But I can get passed it.


Sound:

Voice acting and music is key to any good anime and this one hits every note perfectly.  From the awkward mumbles to the shy "sure" responses everything is done amazingly well.  Also, one of the best opening themes in awhile.  I have it on loop constantly. 


Characters:

From the main roles to the side characters, each is memorable for their role.  Though I personally came to dislike a couple of them but they play key roles to the story.  No character seems out of place.


Enjoyment:

Again,  I still don't know why I love this as much as I do.  I just fell in love with the story and I guess I love going through the wide range of emotions watching it.  


Overall:

I was hooked on the first episode and loved every step (except maybe the re-cap special).  Plus it has possibly the best ending for this genre of anime.  Without giving anything too much away just watch to the very end of episode 12...  I'm seriously fighting off tears writing this and remembering everything.  


Will definitely be binging this completely in the near future.

(Spoiler warning) I cannot think of any other way this anime could improve upon itself which is a part of the reason why I gave it the highest possible score on here. This anime reminded me of my first love but it achieved the ending I always longed for but never managed accomplished (that whore dumped because she wanted to date an Asian >_>) These middle school sweethearts made their long distance work out and ended up getting married even though all the odds of succeeding were against them. His writing got through to her, he convinced her that she wasn't a burden on himeven though she thought other wise, she was actually the glue that held him together. The text format they used to show their relationship worked out was a brand new type of approach and it worked splendidly to articulate the rest of the story without having to have a new season or added OVA's. This love story is the best anime I've experienced and I hope to love someone someday the way they love each other.  This story is a testament that long distance can work if the couple loves each other enough to get though it knowing that they will be close one day in the future.

I dont write reviews for animes I watch. The only time when I feel the need to share my opinion is when I feel really passionate about something. This is one of those passionate things. Now I don't cry when an anime finishes. Most of the time when I watch one, its to pass the time; and maybe one day I'll hit the jackpot and find that one series that really hits me. Tsukigakirei is one of those. 
Story - 10) Granted its not the most original of plotlines, Ive seen plenty other shows with the same premise. HOWEVER, tsukigakirei pulled it off. FUCKING FINALLY,someone did it right. The correct blend of the right characters and plot really goes a long way and this hit a fucking home run in that department. I cannot begin to tell you how long Ive been looking for a series were you have a clear decisive happy ending that shouts "FUCK YOU" to all the haters and harem enthusiasts.


Art - 7) Ok so I cant say an incredible amount about the art, its fairly standard, and- *RING RING*, "2002 called, they want their CGI back." But personally I like to think of the art as perfectly imperfect, and the story makes up for it.


Sound - 9) Yass, its good, music was excellent, fitted well, voicing and actors were well chosen gg wp and all that, sound reviews are boring.


Character - 10) Solid 10 for this, because simliar to the story, the characters arent all that original, butt, they were actually done right this time, character attitudes didn't fluctuate to fit the story, and kota was all too relatable to middle school me. The main characters all had some play in the story line and it all intertwined well.


Enjoyment - 10)

Ive basically summed up why I love this anime so much, but I think it mainly comes back to how much I could relate to it from when I was young, basically the same thing happened to me, except when my girlfreind had to move away we broke up, but I shit you not 4 years later and we're back together. I think thats why it hits home for me, because I always belived in shitty hopeful romance that never worked out until you met that one person, which is where this series works with that.


Overall - 10) Overall, no word of a lie, a true masterpiece of 2017.

Tsuki ga Kirei debuted last spring season and proved to be a beautiful anime series. In 12 episodes a love story is told in its simplest, most pure and honest form.
However, this new anime series stands out from the other series of the genre because, unlike what is customary in Japanese animations, the focus is not on secondary school students. In Tsuki ga Kirei, the characters are attending elementary school. This difference completely alters the whole narrative. Since the characters are in a younger age group, all the questions that revolve around them will inevitably be different.
Tsuki ga Kirei tells the story of Kotaro andAkane, two youngsters in senior year of elementary school. During this last year, the couple will experience a significant experience in the life of any young person: the first love. The anime world is filled with series and films that explore the concept of Tsuki ga Kirei. Some do it with great mastery. Others are a little below expectations. This series depends more on the first option\n
Tsuki ga kirei has a slow start and as the episodes pass, it becomes a real shocking and interesting work, the way to connect akane and kotro make the spectator do not stop accompanying this work\n
The focus of the narrative of Tsuki ga Kirei focuses on the experience of the first love of two young people. It all begins when Kotaro and Akane realize each other's existence. There are many exchanges and deviations of looks, much shyness, much shame. They want to talk to each other, but they do not know the typical anime of the genre. And then, the opportunity arises for the first conversation. Gaining a little courage, there they can share the numbers of mobile phones. This is the first phase of history. The period in which the characters develop a mutual interest for each other and manage to approach in a beautiful way and in some ways not cliché.\n
After the initial approach, the great moment of confession arrives. Unlike other anime, here the confession arrived quite early. For those who accompany anime series of the same genre, know that this is something rare. Most of these series focus the whole drama on the couple's time to express their feelings. However, Tsuki ga Kirei realizes that there is also much drama and conflict in the day-to-day life of a couple. Especially when giving time and space to the characters to have a life, a routine, personal activities that do not involve the boyfriend. So, after a couple of episodes, we have the long-awaited confession.\n\n
Accompanying this romantic journey of Kotaro and Akane is, on the one hand, very funny. Because surely anyone who sees the episodes of the series ends up by reviewing the situations experienced by the characters, creating a certain empathy for them. And that makes this journey also quite nostalgic. Because it reminds us of our own experiences. All this is only possible because the series is highly faithful to reality.\n
After the protagonists express their feelings, they officially start dating. The embarrassment that we saw initially remains, but also shows that the characters are getting more comfortable with each other. And little by little, other adversities and complications appear in the relationship of Kotaro and Akane. For example, try to understand what you are supposed to do as a couple. Or the famous jealousy, the first discussion. Anyway, all that is natural to happen, especially in these ages where the young are still maturing.\n
The drama of the series focuses heavily on these moments, which are essential in a relationship. But it does not become melodramatic or exaggerated. Each of these situations has a purpose. They allow the relationship of Kotaro and Akane to evolve, as does the story itself. But not only. As well as the protagonists growing together, they also do it individually. This is something very important that must be referred to. Another relevant aspect is that the development of each is influenced by the other. It reminds us a little bit what happens to the couple from the movie Mimi wo sumaseba, from Studio ghibli\n
.\n
strong point : The portrait true to the reality of both the characters and the experience of first love.\n
Complaint: The CGI animation. In a beautiful animation that reminds us of Makoto Shinkai's works, it's a shame that the CGI animated parts (eg, crowd animation) are so poorly made. They completely discard the rest\n

Previously on LA's Kuzu no Honkai anime review...
"LA doesn't care if the characters are horrible and hormonal because they can be very relatable thus LA can't really fault these characters because seriously, hormonal teenagers makes dumb mistakes all the time especially from something as complicated and depressing as love let alone unrequited."
Ok...Tsuki ga Kirei is a good puppy love exception it seems.
LA looking at Tsuki ga Kirei quite early on, LA being the extremely cynical type to romance in the media, LA wrote Tsuki ga Kirei off as a cliched puppy love romance story with "expected results", however LA surprisingly quickly over time, LA startedto enjoy this puppy love romance.


If there is something Tsuki ga Kirei does right is how "realistic" the main romance as well as a few of the beta couples do interact with and sure our main romantic couple of Kotarou Azumi voiced by Shouya Chiba, a struggling introverted amateur author and Akane Mizuno voiced by Konomi Kohara, a typical shy yet sociable highschool girl who's in the track team is best summed up as "sickly sweethearts", even their relationship goes through a few trials and tribulations of it's own, from them trying to keep their relationship a secret to their friends, family issues changing their relationship in a big way to jealousy and other love interests to the both of them affecting their relationship. See Tsuki ga Kirei's main romantic plotline has it's cake but has restraint from eating TOO much of it, thus LA can see this as realistic albeit towards sickly sweethearts. Other supporting characters do help move their relationship along be it good or bad, such as the aforementioned love interests (ESPECIALLY towards Chinatsu Nishio voiced by Rie Murakawa, Akane's friend to Azumi was tearjerking to say the least but even then, Chinatsu and Azumi never went on hating each other and by the end of it Chinatsu was one of LA's favourite characters in the anime!), family issues that typically involves school and getting into college was a big factor and once in which oddly enough Junko Azumi voiced by Kikuko Inoue, Azumi's mother was a great benefactor in helping Azumi achieve his goals in many ways (for his future AND his relationship with Akane). Character-wise as much as this isn't relatable to LA, LA KNOWS that the main romance was realistic enough with character depths LA even wasn't expecting from certain characters.


Tsuki ga Kirei also seemed to touch themes on how modern day romance is now played out due to LINE (a real life communication app...no seriously) as well as how millennial's deal with romances as well as achieving your goals, sure that last one sounded cheesy there but even Akane and Azumi has other things to do other than their romance, with Akane's track and Azumi's writing (and even an uncontextualized jab at light novels) it gives them a bit more depth as a characters instead of being stereotypically in love and that's ALL they think about. 


Still from this as much as a focused main romance Tsuki ga Kirei has, it does like to make playful fun scenarios at times and those goes to skits after the after credits, looking at some of the beta couples or minor characters having a bit more of a focus to some skits based around them and they do touch on "how millennial's deal with romances" with a comedic edge to them. LA's favourite skits would be ANYTHING focusing on Ryouka Sonoda voiced by Nao Touyama.


LA has to say that for an original anime done by Studio feel, this was one hell of a surprise from them as LA at the start was indifferent to Studio feel. but over time with Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru. Zoku, Oshiete! Galko-chan and Kono Bijutsubu ni wa Mondai ga Aru!, they seemed to have honed in, in what they are good at, that being realistic with a funny edge animes (genre varies) and has become a more reliable anime company to say the least as LA writes this and Tsuki ga Kirei is another great example for Studio feel.


In terms of animation by Studio feel, LA really liked the characters designs and although it suffered from a bit of same face syndrome, some of the characters were recognizable just for their actions alone and NOT their appearance. The backgrounding was gorgeous to be expected although there is only one gripe with the animation and that goes to the awful CGI used within the backgrounds. LA has a rule about CGI and that is if it's used on humans, IT NEEDS TO BE DONE IN GREAT DETAIL or make the entire thing CGI otherwise there will be an uncanny effect making them like lifeless dolls and that soured the backgrounds ALL the time. But nonetheless, the animation was used well for the most part and gave some gorgeous scenery.


In terms of voice acting, well having newbie seiyuu's like Shouya Chiba and Konomi Kohara was pretty good in this anime and although there a veterans and mainstay seiyuu's in this anime voice cast like Nao Touyama, Kikuko Inoue, Chiwa Saito and Haruka Chigusa, this voice cast was stellar giving major props to both Shouya Chiba and Konomi Kohara in this regard. Now LA usually doesn't talk soundtrack and music but this NEEDS to be said and the entire soundtrack, Opening and Ending themes are covered by Nao Touyama and her calming vocals. LA just loved this soundtrack including the Opening as well and LA want to see more from Nao Touyama in this area AS well as more from her in terms of character roles in the future (Nao Touyama fanboy speaking here if that's not obvious).


Tsuki ga Kirei is one of the hidden gems of Spring 2017 for LA and for someone like LA, a cynical person in viewing romance in the media let alone puppy love romances bloom like this in a reasonable and realistic way and even having LA's approval in the ways it's executed with it's strengths of it's many characters and themes it vehemently upholds along with a tearjerking finale is some feat for Tsuki ga Kirei. Sure it will turn some people away looking for darker romances instead of this schmaltzy played out romance, but Tsuki ga Kirei does it's job well in portraying a sickly sweethearts puppy love romance with it's trials and tribulations it entails.


Hey, LA might be a cynical bastard when looking at romance in the media, if the romance however schmaltzy has heart and a good story, it can warm the most cynical of romanticists....hopefully.

Really looking forward to the next season. This show displays the awkwardness of dating at a younger age could relate to some of you. Overall I recommend this show to anyonewho likes romance!

"If there is such a thing as god of fate, he must be quite a troll" 
quote of the year! 
Tsuki ga Kirei is a love story too pure for the 21st century. It's like the anime that will make you want to get back with the ex girlfriend that you never had. It's a very sweet, innocent tale of two innocent kids from two very different worlds who cross paths and fall in love. The anime depicts their relationship when it's at a very premature stage, They don't know what to do or expect and it makes you curious in what direction they willgo. It focuses on their trails and tribulations of trying to overcoming peer pressure, family pressure and focusing on one's ambition.


This is an anime original so i didn't know what to expect when I started this and it was quite underrated during the start of spring but I'm glad it became a little more popular, it gained quite a momentum towards the end and I hope it continues to be more successful.


The two main characters are really great, they are very relatable, even if you have never been in a relationship (I know i haven't been in one) they really resonate with you. They are portrayed as realistic as possible and they have moments where, you know, being the main character of the show didn't help them, which was quite refreshing honestly. This whole anime is a beautiful struggle and it's great to watch them grow and develop from being shy introverted characters to making some bold decisions. It just makes you wanna root for them.


The animation was pretty good, the art was simple but effective, it set a tone that fit well with the location and the atmosphere of the anime. It feels very nostalgic. The music is the real deal though, the songs are so good and the soundtrack compliments the romantic vibe so well you might even skip a beat. Oh! and I would be stupid to leave out the after credit monologues in every episodes, that alone makes this show worth watching!


But I can see some people who might find this anime to be boring, it's quite slow and the cellphone LINE conversations that they often have throughout the show might have people rolling their eyes. I didn't really have a big problem with it but I can see people calling this out, if you're not a fan of romance in general and find it to be a corny genre, I can't guarantee that this will change your mind. The problem I had with this show are the side characters, some of their behavior is just cliché and annoying. None of them are explored and they lack screen time, personally to me they come off as very one dimensional.


But yeah, Overall it was a very good anime and I really enjoyed it. It has a lot of elements that make it truly worthwhile. If you're a fan of the romance genre, this is an anime that you cannot miss.


My rating:- 7.5/10

*This Review contains spoilers*
When I first went in to Tsuki ga Kirei I have to admit I got about 4 episodes in and dropped it for a solid 3 months. It just wasn’t entertaining enough, but then I came back to it when I was craving some romance and SoL. And I will admit again that even though I enjoyed it and liked it a lot there were times I found myself dozing off. But this time I chugged through my drowsyness and finished it and I got to say it was by far one of the best anime I’ve seen in a long time,just because of the ending.


Story-10

The story is pretty simple, boy meets girl, boy likes girl, girl also likes boy, they start dating. Simple, clean, and nice. They actually start dating pretty early on which is always a plus. After that it’s basically just the simple relationship drama with another girl liking the boy another guy liking the girl. But it’s not a drama heavy series with what drama it does have not really making you scared that they are going to break up or anything like that. 


Art-7

The art is lackluster at best, there’s no real moments when you just look at it and think to yourself “wow that is some good art” there’s a few and I mean a few moments when the animation is perfection but like most anime they are rare and short. 


Sound-6

I got to be honest I’ve never been that picky with sound unless it was like an old anime with bad sound but this has just the same old same old anime sounds. The voice acting is pretty good in my opinion, the VAs really give the characters their well...... character by being quiet, shy, and not all that outgoing.


Character-9

Oh boy how I loved these characters, Kotarō Azumi is a pretty likable guy. He’s pretty quiet and not the most outgoing guy but he’s interesting. He’s attracted to Akane Mizuno pretty early on and actually becomes texting buddies with her fairly quickly. Which in turn let’s you see one of the best character traits I’ve seen in awhile. When he texts with Akane and he gets super happy or asks a big question he’ll jump up from his bed and start “boxing” his light switch that’s  hanging down and I always love that, I find it to be very funny and pretty relatiable to be honest.there is some other characters in there that are kinda interesting like the other love interests but they are not part of my review I am only talking about the 2 main characters.


*Spoiler heavy section*


Enjoyment-10

Like I said above I got bored with this series early on and when I came back I still had some boring spots to watch, but where my overall enjoyment of this series comes from, why I’ve given it an outstanding 10/10 on Mal and why I’m even writing a review about it in the first place is the ENDING. And holy crap is it the BEST ending I’ve ever seen in an anime EVER.IF YOU DONT LIKE SPOILERS STOP READING NOW!!! So this anime’s ending isn’t actually what I’m talking about though I’m talking about the ending CREDITS yah that’s right the end credits. The ending itself is pretty good with the girl going away and the boy chasing after the train a yelling out to her while she reads his text explaining how he loves her so so so much. Which in itself is really good but then the creators of this anime go a step further and during the credits(god save you if you missed em) it shows pictures and the texts they send each other throughout their LIVES!!! Yah their whole lives with them having long distance that actually works(SAY WHAT) and then them getting jobs and moving in together and living together and getting MARRIED and having a KID!!!! It’s honestly adorable and the cutest thing ever. And is totally worth watching all of it just for that. It made me happy cry, I cried so hard watching it but of just pure happiness because they truly love each other soooo much and you see that in the end credits. It’s not only the best ending I’ve ever seen but also the most satisfying ending I’ve ever seen you see what happens to these characters you’ve watched for 12 episodes. And you just feel such happiness for them. 


*End spoiler section*


Overall-10 

like I said before my most enjoyment came from the end credits. That is why I gave this anime a 10/10 and why im even writing a review about it in the first place. I highly recommend this anime to anyone who’s a fan of romance or SoL. You won’t find a more satisfying or happy anime anywhere else and if you’ve already seen it which I’m guessing most of you have. TELL YOUR FRIENDS!!! You may not have the patience to watch a whole anime just for the ending but its definitely worth it and there’s still plenty of good moments in between that really let you get to love the characters. 


Phew wow that was my first full length review on an anime and I think I did pretty good(I hope I did at least) I hope I got some people to watch it and I definitely hope I might’ve changed some people’s minds on what they think about it.

This is my first review. These are my feelings of the anime in regards to how I liked it, not necessarily how I think most people would like it.
This is a spoiler-free review.
The story isn't phenomenal, but it's realistic and consistent. It's exactly what it says it is and does exactly what it sets out to do - to tell a story of a bunch of middle-schoolers in Japan. Though I tend to enjoy slice-of-life, I was mildly disappointed at its simplicity. 5/10
I really like the art style used in this anime - it's probably my favorite of all anime I've seen thus far. Theonly other anime of feel.'s that I've seen is Oregairu, so I didn't know what the studio's style was really going to be like, but I was quite impressed even just after the first episode. The only complaint I have is that the crowds look like absolute garbage to the point that I thought they were incomplete for some odd reason. 9/10, still.


I personally don't care much for vocal music outside of OPs and EDs, and this anime had enough instances of its use to annoy me just a little. The background music the rest of the time isn't anything phenomenal, but it's by no means poor. 5/10


The characters were well-crafted, though that's easy enough to do considering the genre and the amount of characters that the anime cared to delve into (I'd argue only two and maybe three characters get flushed out to the point of satisfaction). Interactions are natural and the studio does a very good job of imitating middle-school life, which turns out to be both a positive and a negative for this anime in my opinion. Again, nothing and nobody amazing or genre-defining by any means, but a pretty decent cast all the same. 7/10


Though I enjoy slice-of-life, I realise it probably has the most potential of any genre to be incredibly boring. While that 's part of what makes up my overall lack of enjoyment, the kicker is how close to reality it is, as I mentioned in the previous paragraph. I'm not too far out of middle school myself, and the anime pretty successfully reminded me of several instances of awkwardness and cringe that only the environment of a middle-school can so masterfully produce. I personally watch slice-of-life anime to enjoy what a realistic yet fortunate life can turn out to be; it gives one a sense of hope and contentment. This anime has the inverse effect. Now, if your middle-school experience wasn't so bad as to periodically give you flashbacks that make you want to die, or you're old enough to have the memories be much fuzzier, then you'll probably have a decent chance at enjoying this anime. However, given my age and circumstance, I did not.

Still, some moments were enjoyable. The romance wasn't so bad, though a little slow. The parts I looked forward to the most were the ends of the episodes, where we get to see what the other characters were up to. Those were fun. 3/10


Overall, 6/10. I could probably rate even lower, but the title's too good for a five.

I'm never had such a good feeling in my heart from watching an anime. The music mixed the beautiful scenery was just outstanding. The pause in the music when he said "I love you" was my favorite scene because it shows he is taking action. Love is all about who has the courage to make a change and a single sentence can change the fate of who you will be with and be happy with for the rest of your life. If you don't say anything then that person will be swept away by someone else's love that rivaled yours. The final scene with theirbaby was truly beautiful. They all had the red ribbon of fate on their pinkie representing that there love was decided from the beginning.

Tsuki Ga Kirei is a story about first love, young love and making love work through hardships.
Story & Characters: The Story centers around Akane and Kotaru, two junior high students who through a series of coincidences fall in love. They have different hobbies, friends and situations. You follow their lives as they go through their last year before highschool, with love triangles, jealousy, nervousness and other feelings being major themes. The story is beautifully written, but has e few small bumps in it's road. One of these bumps is the lack of backstory for many of the characters. The characters themselves all have their ownpersonality and avoid falling into the usual tropes, but has little backstory. This is not a major problem as they are young and therefore wouldn't usually have a long story, but some more backstory would not have hurt. The story tackles many issues in a relatively realistic way and thereby gets easier to insert yourself into.\n
Art & Sound: The art is probably the big let down in this anime, with not the best drawn characters (though the background are well done) adn a large use of bad CGI animations for characters moving in the background, making it somewhat awkward to watch. The sound is solid, but not exactly  enough to send me to heaven, just good.\n
Overall: I enjoyed the show a lot and watched everything in just two sessions. I can recommend this show for fans of slice of life or romance stories, and I ask not to judge the art to harshly.\n
Enjoy!

Definitely one of the best school-life, romance animes ever. I had never watched a school romance anime until coming across this masterpiece. I have a list of my personal top list of romance anime and Tsuki ga Kirei is definitely one of the few on the top of my list. 
One of the best things about this story is how original the plot is, how it gets straight to the point. At the start we are introduced with our 2 main protagonists, who will eventually fall in love and become a couple. They are just 2 students in their last year of junior high, aboutto move on in life and go to high school. Their relation starts with the usual awkwardness, shyness and anxiety between 2 teenagers of the opposite sex. As the story progresses, we are able to see how they are able to try and surpass these issues. I definitely feel that this anime is so enjoyable because many of us can relate to them, and how they feel. Another thing I really enjoyed and was grateful for was that even though there were love triangles, the plot doesn't expand much on that and mainly focuses on the main relation between the 2 teenagers, Akane and Koutarou. There were no typical anime 'cliches' and was just a simple romance story about 2 normal teenagers. 


The anime had decent visual artwork, and the music and songs were great too, with many of the soundtracks coming in at the right moment in the story to produce a masterpiece for many of us to enjoy. The characters were well developed and even the extra, secondary characters added some atmosphere to the story. 


The only thing that I really felt disappointed about was that I felt the ending was a bit rushed. I would have enjoyed a second season or even an OVA to let the audience understand what happened to them later on in life and let us truly say goodbye to the 2. 


Overall I felt that this was a truly outstanding anime and definitely deserves a 9/10. However, if you aren't looking for any romance stories and looking for action or anything different, I wouldn't suggest this anime for you.

If any of you haven't watched Tsuki ga Kirei please go ahead and watch it unless you hate romance or slice of life . Completed this treasure yesterday and still have lingering feelings from when I watched the ending. I personally hate even the most vague of spoilers. So I will also do my best to avoid such situations even though I know it is difficult to do.
The story journeys the lives of 2 middle school students that were just classmates until a recent series of meetings/events entwined their fates. It is a very cute , innocent , and pure anime that really draws youin emotionally because you can totally relate to most of the things that happen within the anime. We all have our first loves , first girlfriends and first kisses that we all treasure . We cherish the feeling of comfort and pleasure these emotions give and it really incites you to think back on your past.


Tsuki ga Kirei confronts the common challenges faced in every relationship (e.g uncertainty and many more ,please watch to find out ) and shows a beautiful way of how these young teenagers face each challenge. 


It is an anime that makes you reflect on your past (if you can relate) and give you a sense of comfort and ease.


It does a good job of combining drama with romance and it even manages to include some wholesome comedic relief. 


I love the Art Style , its not the usual pen and marker 3D animation , but sadly i don't know how to describe the art. I would say it looks like paint but not really? Anyways, it is really refreshing and it totally fits the mood and vibe the content gives. 


Voice acting was amazingly done by Kohara Konomi and Chiba Shoya, their voices by itself are soothing and lively but it was elevated to greater heights their passion and emotion . I absolutely love how Konomi (Akane) sounds in this anime , it just sounds so natural and bright . OST's are one of the most important things to make an anime shine and they do it perfectly in this series. ED is good but OP is even better. 



Overall , Tsuki ga Kirei is a must watch for anyone that enjoys Romance, Slice of life. I personally rate it 11/10 and it's good enough for me to crown it my Favourite romance anime immediately after I finished it . I think this is also a good choice or anyone who would like to venture out of Action or Shounen as well. 


Last but not least , another reason Tsuki ga Kirei is remarkably wholesome and satisfactory because it doesn't leave you hanging like every other anime there is ;)

Short and sweet review. Do you know what to expect from romance anime and are tired of people pointing out the "genre stereotypes" and then judging the anime only around that? Just want to know the important stuff and if you should watch it? I've got you covered.
This show is my new standard for good romance anime. I literally can not heap enough praise onto this show, and that is a major surprise because it is set in middle school.
Tsuki ga Kirei is one of those rare romance animes that hit all the right spots and stick the landing every time. Not only is thepacing epic, especially for a 13 episode show, but the characters are realistic and enticing, the story-line is dramatic without being unrealistic, and the main character's romance actually progresses in a natural way thanks to them being humans instead of weird Japanese romance trope robots who do nothing but blush. I will address each of these things in order below.


The pacing of this show is great. There is no boring episodes, or filler story, or superfluous exposition. Every episode has a complete beginning, middle, and ending arc but is part of the overall 13 episode story. Every time the credits hit, you will be scrambling to start the next episode. The entire pacing of the show hinges on the romance and not some other stupid school-related story or side character or random plot point like so many other romances NEED in order to fill out a season.


The characters are what make this show how great it is. They are middle-school aged, so the first episode they can barely look at each other. Sounds familiar right? Except they will surprise you at EVERY turn. Not because their reactions or interactions are crazy or outlandish, but because they ARE NOT. Their reactions are so human. And their reactions to what others say and do are believable and well thought out. They will also change right before your eyes in the best ways possible. The male lead CONSTANTLY grows a pair at the best moments, "manning up" in situations where characters in other anime would wimp out, run away, or take another half-season to even consider doing something. The female lead does the same thing, not wimping out or failing to speak their mind at key moments, not running away, etc. It was SO refreshing to see a romance take shape so quickly, yet still so naturally. The side characters are all well thought out and have their role to play, but don't become the center of attention at any point nor do they have any unnecessary development that isn't required for their part. They are there as a foil and as soon as they play their part they are not important anymore and have less scenes.


Rather than avoiding the normal romance anime pitfalls, Tsuki ga Kirei just plows right through them. Awkward moments? One of the characters mans up. Side-character confesses? Barely even 1 episode total spent dealing with it. Missed opportunity for a kiss/hug/etc? Happens anyway moments later or the next episode. Every time this show will surprise you with where it goes, because we've all been so conditioned by anime like Kimi ni Todoke or Toradora to think that romance developments can only happen if they are painfully slow paced, and only when the main characters have been oblivious/shy/stupid when it comes to the romance for at least 50% of the show.


And oh my god the feels in this show. I found myself pausing several times to just take a breath, and for once it wasn't because I was frustrated. Usually it was because I was generally happy or I was sad about something that had just happened. Your heartstrings will be yanked on dozens of times throughout this show and only in the best ways. There were more genuinely HAPPY moments in this show than most other anime I have watched, along with several moments that made me jump out of my seat and cheer out loud.


Watch this show. If you love romance anime, watch it. If you hate romance anime, watch it. If you used to love romance anime, definitely watch it. You will not be disappointed.


THIS IS A PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT FOR ANYONE WHO LIKES HAPPY ENDINGS IN THEIR ROMANCE ANIME (VERY MILD SPOILER WARNING AHEAD):


THIS SHOW HAS A HAPPY ENDING! However, you won't know that it does unless you watch the credits of the last episode. The way the episode ends before the credits you may think it either ended badly or in the traditional "That PROBABLY happened but we won't know because it's the end!" kinda way. But that's not the case! Be sure to be ready to PAUSE playback, as the ending is mostly a slideshow of moments in the future that occur after the story in the last episode ends. You'll be reading LINE messages between characters from future events for the most part, so be sure to watch and read everything. The final shot before the end of the credits will give you all the closure you need :) Great ending, despite my desire for more.


HIGHLIGHTS: The male character has a set of balls, the female character isn't stupid, the characters actually EVOLVE within the beginning of the show as well as the end, the music is great, the animation is unique (even though it's been done similarly before), your heartstrings will be tugged in legitimate ways, and the ending is HAPPY!


DISAPPOINTMENTS: It wasn't longer, "epilogue" is just still images/chat messages from milestones in their lives after middle-school, there is no sequel at all (not even an OVA)


Note: I re-wrote this review to match the quality of my more recent ones on 9/13/2018. Originally posted 8/13/208.

Now, a High School Romance is the first thing that comes to my mind when asked about Anime Romance. My Experiences with High School Romance anime have been mostly on the comedic side, some are done brilliantly, whilst others... Not so much.
However, watching this anime was quite a hollow moment for me.
Why?
Well... When I watch a good anime, I get a tingly feeling, what I would describe as a "fizz". That 'fizz' raises the bar for the next anime I watch.
Again, how does it feel hollow?
Welp.
It's because I will now, live with the fact that I will never quite find another anime that would giveme a bigger "fizz" then when I was watching Tsuki ga Kirei for years and years to come. 


----------------------------------------------------------------


I have always had a love/hate relationship with Original animes, as compared to the animes based on a novel. Why?


It's because in an Original anime if the story ends... that's it. There is no Manga to carry on the story, you just have to sit there, waiting, praying that it will carry on.


However, when I think about it, Tsuki ga Kirei made me sad yet happy, I would rather have it end that way, then to suddenly lift the spirit up. This is why we don't have a second Plastic Memories.


----------------------------------------------------------------

Tsuki Ga Kirei had a lot of fun, thrilled me, arrested me, and most of all: I left happy. It's an anime that will be forever on my kokoro and on my favorite list & lt

This anime is just about as refreshing as a hot, steamy shower after a long day.
